data.title: Why hasn't a viable alternative to Exchange/Outlook been created yet?
data.meta_description: Just wondering, I have been having this discussion with some co-workers recently. I am talking about a open source email system that can more or less...
data.text:
quote:
Originally posted by jwbaker:
Programmers don't like Exchange. As an email server Exchange is a joke, and Exchange's other features don't appeal to open source/Free Software hackers at all. For example, the ability to tell when your colleague reads your message, or the ability to un-send a message, are concepts totally repulsive to your average open source contributor.


Bingo.

If they wanted it then they'd just use Exchange. People that don't like Exchange don't want to re-create it.

The deal is that Exchange is a groupware product. Groupware itself is one of those obsolete concepts that grew out of limited NetBiue-style networks. They thought it would be a good idea that you have one monolythic service that will provide all your business needs. Messaging, document handling, etc etc. So there is all this massive amount of functionality smooshed into one single product.

Not very many people want to re-create that. OSS folks tend to come from a Unix-like background with TCP/IP-style networks were you deal with lots of specialized servers.

If you look around you can find 'Exchange alternatives' like O-xchange or Zimbra
http://wiki.samba.org/index.ph..._Server_Alternatives

But generally speaking...

So, for example, if you want email, then simply deploy a IMAP server and a SMTP server. To go along with that you can deploy a LDAP server for centralized database for tracking users. This sort of thing generally outperforms any Exchange system at a fraction of the cost. It's not easy, but email is a huge PITA no matter what you do, but it's cheap and option for anti-spam and such is very effective.

Lots of webmail options...

Need a way to do quick messaging and away notifications? Jabber.

Need a way to provide company information from different departments to everybody inhouse? A intranet with a decent CMS works well.

All sorts of different forums software is avialable.

You can manage documents using regular file sharing or webdav. Nowadays even open source programs like O rg have the ability to do collaberation with various extensions and whatnot.

It all depends on your business needs and this is why there is no 'standard package' to do all this stuff with. Everybody creates a custom solution based on their own needs rather then forcing their business to conform to some monolythic application.

That's not to say that everything is all happy and wonderful, of course. I think that Calendering is one major thing that people are missing.

-----------------------

Besides the lack of a Exchange alternative there is enough problems with the Linux desktop and things like OpenOffice.org and the difficulty of replicating Active Directory-like functionality with Linux desktops is holding back adoption in a big way.

If your stuck using Windows desktops and Microsoft Office then nothing compares to Windows Servers in terms of integration and support. Everybody else is a minor player. When you (in this example Microsoft) controls the platform your users are using then they can very effectively dictate the software your going to run on the server.

In other words: Microsoft Office means Microsoft Windows. Microsoft Windows means your running Microsoft Server. Microsoft Server means Active Directory and other Microsoft services. If your running Microsoft Office and your running Microsoft Server then it's a no-brainer for most people just to run Microsoft Exchange.
quote:
Originally posted by Nothinman:
quote:
Seems like the client is more or less there already with Thunderbird.


Not really. A huge aspect of Outlook/Exchange is the calendar integration and sharing so until there's a mail server with calendaring like Exchange and Thunderbird fully supports it there is no alternative.


There are always alternatives, else Windows couldn't have been viable to replace some subset of single-application Unix workstations that had much more functionality.

In the end, the market decides if an option has the required functionality or not. So far, no single, integrated, open source solution has come close to a critical mass of mindshare to begin to compete with Exchange, Notes, and Groupwise. As individual pieces, open source MTAs, MUAs, LDAs, directories, CMSes, and calendering solutions are extremely popular. Zimbra might be the farthest ahead with an integrated, branded solution, but they aren't remotely close to any tipping point yet.

Open source solutions tend not to be centralized and they tend not to suffer so much from feature creep; more frequently they are combined. For any given piece you might use in FOSS mail/groupware package, some other package would be a viable competitor. In fact, the way to go is not to specify the solution end to end, but the protocols and standards.

Mail in and out: SMTP
Client content retrieval and manipulation: IMAPv4, HTTP (web interface), POP3
Directory: LDAP
Collaboration: HTTP, WebDAV
Calendering: iCalender (RFC2445), HTTP

So the server solution doesn't confin you to Outlook for calendering, you use any iCalender client (which happens to include Apple, Google, IBM/Lotus, Microsoft, Novell, and Sun solutions as well as a dozen open source apps). Maybe your IT department picks one to support, but they still have a lot of iCalender protocol options if they want to migrate from Windows to OS X in the future (or Linux to Sun Ray for that matter).

There's still a ton of room for integrators and support organizations to build and tune full solutions from existing open source pieces, it just hasn't happened a lot yet.
quote:
Originally posted by BlackHex:
Implementing all of the above in a good form is a huge task, and requires a level of vision and direction the OSS world is not known for. And even if they built it it would only gain useful traction if almost the entire OSS world agreed to use it.


Your acting like Exchange is god's own MTA. All users care about is the pixels on the screen, they couldn't really give a crap what else is going on even though they'll tell you otherwise.

Exchange sucks, Outlook sucks, but once people are used to how something works, how something looks, then they have a huge amount of resistance to any change. That is a reality that nobody can do anything about and it's a very tough nut to crack. Inertia is the best word for it.

quote:
That fits the needs of a large amount of organizations out there. Linux market share on the desktop would probably soar. There are a LOT of users out there who just need to use Word, Excel and Outlook. We already have the Word and Excel part taken care of. Then, once the market share starts bumping up from the light users, more development might start for the specialized applications.


It's the whole package.

A low-skilled tech can go and purchase a hundred Dell boxes, get a Windows Server or two, and throw together a entire "Domain" in a weekend of work. Very strong Kerberos authentication, LDAP directory server, email, messaging, calendering, file sharing, remote configuration, user management, etc etc. They don't have to know about how any of it works or even what the authentication protocol is called. They just throw it all together and everything is pre-configured to work together. Most of the work is already done by Microsoft long before any end user touches it.

In comparison a average tech person working with Linux for the first time is going to spend weeks farting around with Sendmail until they realize that it's shit and strip it out of their Redhat boxes for something like Postfix. Then another weekend spent learning about mail and getting all that working. And that is just one tiny piece of the puzzle.

I mean everything works together just fine. You can do most anything with Linux that you can do with Windows.

But..

For example: LDAP. LDAP isn't very difficult to deal with. Like anything making it 'enterprise' requires a lot of work, but all software is like that. Working with it isn't very difficult, fundamentally. But the simple fact of trying to configure it to get OpenLDAP _going_ is terrifically difficult. A lot of people play with something like OpenLDAP can't get past just getting the stupid thing to work, then give up completely.

---------------------------------

So until we can get something like a 'Ubuntu Server' and stick that on a network with it's default configurations, and then throw a ubuntu install cdrom on 2 dozen PCs and have a working Linux-based domain 45 minutes later (that works with Windows, too, btw) ... then Linux isn't going to beat Windows on the Desktop. (and even then it's not going to beat it, but it can give it a much better chance)

If we can get that then that gives people something to really work with. Get something that 'just works'. As in completely automatically.

Then you can use that as a basis for extending it to make it work in your organization and doing more complex things. Having a good default, working, configuration administrators is critical. It provides a nice basis for, a 75% solution, that you can then really sink your teeth into and get working.

-----------------------------

It's like Ubuntu vs Debian. Debian provides almost all the software that Ubuntu uses, already tested, already packaged. Gnome usability improvements are due in huge part to Novell's work on it. OpenOffice.org is from Sun. etc etc. What Ubuntu actually creates, in terms of improvements and software, is tiny compared to Redhat and is even minor compared to what Debian does.

But for a very long time the default configuration you'd get from Debian was virtually unusable. It required a lot of work just to get it to work well. Ubuntu got a crapload of attention because they were the ones that finally were able to perform the configuration and tweaking that made Debian usable by a much wider audience. The good default Ubuntu install is the "magic" that they were able to do to get so much attention in a short time, when other people like Suse have been plodding around for years.

And that's not me trying to downplay Ubuntu or saying Debian does all the work or whatever... making software work for and actually be usable by a large number of diverse users is terrifically difficult. The amount of ignorance that always shows up on this topic is simulanteously overwhelming and depressing. I doubt I can address it all.

quote:
Originally posted by drag:
The deal is that Exchange is a groupware product. Groupware itself is one of those obsolete concepts that grew out of limited NetBiue-style networks.
No, it isn't.

quote:
So, for example, if you want email, then simply deploy a IMAP server and a SMTP server. To go along with that you can deploy a LDAP server for centralized database for tracking users. This sort of thing generally outperforms any Exchange system at a fraction of the cost.
Not really, no. There's only one or two IMAP servers out there than can keep pace with Exchange and Domino on the high-end.

And I don't think there are any that are truly as featureful, when you get right down to it.

quote:
Originally posted by M. Jones:
In fact, the way to go is not to specify the solution end to end, but the protocols and standards.
No, it isn't. Lotus, MS, and Novell didn't get to where they are by paying attention to protocols and standards, if you'll note. Protocols and standards are bloody well-irrelevant. To suggest anything else is ignorant of the marketplace.

Moreover, the protocols we have are inadequate, as-is. That's part of the problem, fundamentally.

quote:
So the server solution doesn't confin you to Outlook for calendering, you use any iCalender client (which happens to include Apple, Google, IBM/Lotus, Microsoft, Novell, and Sun solutions as well as a dozen open source apps).
No business wants to do this. No business wants to support a multitude of calendaring solutions, they'll standardize on one to save their IT costs and keep the hassle down. As such, if your calendar is good enough, no one cares about interoperability. Oh sure, some people will bitch, but if it's good enough, they'll swallow the bullet.

quote:
Originally posted by neilhwatson:
I would argue that most users want Outlook because it is all they've every known and don't want to risk change.
This is easily the most absurd thing said in the thread, but don't let it stop you.

quote:
Originally posted by rob3r:
Seems like the killer feature that OSS is missing is shared calendaring (my co-workers and I brought that point up and agreed as well).
Nope, not at all. The directory services suck and the administration-level integration sucks. The client is secondary if the backend sucks; how else do you explain Notes?

I mean, yes, it's missing good shared calendaring, but that's not the key that will solve the problem.

quote:
Originally posted by drag:
Exchange sucks, Outlook sucks, but once people are used to how something works, how something looks, then they have a huge amount of resistance to any change.
They're honsetly better than anything else out there in the market and you'd be insane not to realize and accept that.

That, in and of itself, makes them "good" products in some sense, since they're the standard to beat.

quote:
For example: LDAP. LDAP isn't very difficult to deal with. Like anything making it 'enterprise' requires a lot of work, but all software is like that.
Except Active Directory! Funny that.

And no, LDAP on Linux is incredibly difficult, complicated, and convoluted to work with. The amount of understanding required to implement it is asinine. Especially OpenLDAP, though FDS isn't nearly as bad. Of course you say this, which means your paragraph was a walking contradiction.

quote:
Originally posted by stmiller:
I was trying to make a broader generalization about the MS admin world vs. Linux admin world.

The person made a comment about a mail program needing a 'nice admin back end'.
And they do. The issue isn't so much the nature of such a backend, but the raw lack of integration between parts, and massive differences between configuration files and layout.
quote:
Originally posted by drag:
So until we can get something like a 'Ubuntu Server' and stick that on a network with it's default configurations, and then throw a ubuntu install cdrom on 2 dozen PCs and have a working Linux-based domain 45 minutes later (that works with Windows, too, btw) ... then Linux isn't going to beat Windows on the Desktop. (and even then it's not going to beat it, but it can give it a much better chance)

If we can get that then that gives people something to really work with. Get something that 'just works'. As in completely automatically.

Then you can use that as a basis for extending it to make it work in your organization and doing more complex things. Having a good default, working, configuration administrators is critical. It provides a nice basis for, a 75% solution, that you can then really sink your teeth into and get working.


This. Good defaults and fast fixes.

How many times have I looked at a manpage recently, wishing for a section called "This is probably what you want to do" with a handful of examples of the most common use cases? Eh, at least most of the information is in Linux manpages now, instead of "Check the GNU Info page!" or "Type stupidbinary --help --gnu-double-dashes-suck because we can't remember to maintain a manpage!" (BSD and commercial Unix FTW, there).

Or how about an AD compatible default schema for OpenLDAP? None of this schema relativism stuff, just start the manual with "You probably want to do a) this task, or b) this other task. We'll give the summary of those two up front, and the rest of the manual will be full documentation and witty repartee, OK?"

Windows was always good for getting something working quick because Microsoft had a direction and an agenda and few standards to worry about. And a GUI that the unskilled could click around in, instead of whipping off a 53-character find, sed, and awk work of art. Of course the thing you got working with Windows might not be what you needed, and then you were in for some pain. Open source products have to spend a lot more effort on compatibility, and they need to spend more time on out-of-box experience.
quote:
Originally posted by LordHunter317:]
quote:
Originally posted by M. Jones:
In fact, the way to go is not to specify the solution end to end, but the protocols and standards.
No, it isn't. Lotus, MS, and Novell didn't get to where they are by paying attention to protocols and standards, if you'll note. Protocols and standards are bloody well-irrelevant. To suggest anything else is ignorant of the marketplace.

Moreover, the protocols we have are inadequate, as-is. That's part of the problem, fundamentally.


I know what gets used is reflective of the marketplace. Standards lead to commodification and best-of-breed solutions, instead of single vendor lock-in. I'm not disputing Microsoft's business strategy in taking their torrent of DOS royalties and creating Windows, and MS Mail, and CIFS, and MAPI and all of the other proprietary stuff. I'm disputing the value of locked-in solutions to those that buy them.

And protocols can always get better, and they do. Interop and standards are no longer about copyright or trademarks, they're about patents, but that's another discussion. Last week I stumbled across a 2003 patent on doing a DNS lookup with one apparatus and supplying relevant data to another apparatus.

quote:
Originally posted by drag:
quote:
For example: LDAP. LDAP isn't very difficult to deal with. Like anything making it 'enterprise' requires a lot of work, but all software is like that.
Except Active Directory! Funny that.


Non sequitur. Apples and oranges. Active Directory uses LDAP as a transport, and can sorta be a generic LDAP server probably. OpenLDAP does a lot more. Active Directory is a schema, and uses standard LDAP, and a version of MIT's open source Kerberos, and has some management tools. AD's most important asset is that it has a huge potential user base because Windows 2000 and later use it by default, and it comes free with Microsoft operating systems. Yes, the fact that AD has a default schema out of the box is very good, but 90% of the value of AD is directly the result of Microsoft owning the PC bootloader.
quote:
Originally posted by M. Jones:
Standards lead to commodification and best-of-breed solutions, instead of single vendor lock-in.
Funny, the "best-of-breed" solutions aren't standards-base. You're spouting tautologies with no basis in reality.

quote:
I'm disputing the value of locked-in solutions to those that buy them.
Clearly, it's more than the "commodified", "best-of-breed", "standards-based" solutions. There's nothing to dispute here.

quote:
Non sequitur. Apples and oranges. Active Directory uses LDAP as a transport, and can sorta be a generic LDAP server probably.
It's not a non-sequitur in the least; and it's not an apples and oranges comparsion. This response shows you missed the point altogether: people don't want to dick around with an LDAP server. They want to click a few buttons and have a centralized place to handle accounts and passwords. Linux makes this hard. Windows makes this stupidly easy.

Also, it does seems show is you're not aware of what the limits on AD compliance with LDAPv3 are[1]

quote:
AD's most important asset is that it has a huge potential user base because Windows 2000 and later use it by default, and it comes free with Microsoft operating systems.
No, it isn't, but you're welcome to believe that. The fact that it "just works" for what most people want a directory server for is its biggest asset.

[1]It's not apparent anyone does, to be fair. But it is as much as of an LDAP directory as anything else, save for some oddball limitations. AFAICT, by and by large, they're not impossible to deal with. I'm hardly an expert, though.
quote:
Originally posted by Coleman:
The problem I always seem to see when people rip on Exchange(especially from the Linux front around me) is they say "Exchange is a sucky email server". Except...Postfix is a sucky calendar, information sharing, web front end server. Far too many people think of Exchange as Microsoft's mail server when that is only the one part of what Exchange is.

We already know Postfix is just an MTA. It's also not an MUA or a recipe organizer. The full mail solution is something like Postfix + Dovecot + Apache + Roundcube, plus OpenLDAP if you want directory services, plus a CMS or mailscanning package, etc. Don't forget that Exchange is a sucky web front end server, too, which is why it uses IIS, and that it doesn't have CMS which is why it uses Sharepoint, and it doesn't have filtering or antispam which is why it uses something third party where you need to make a choice instead of buying from Microsoft.

And for that matter, I've already said why Exchange is a sucky email server. I'll even quote myself:
quote:
Originally posted by M. Jones:
* Outlook isn't available on most of my platforms.

* Outlook top posts by default [...].

* Outlook/Exchange primarily uses proprietary protocols for client-server communication.

* Outlook doesn't support "+" mailbox addressing.

* Outlook/Exchange's licensing model is a pain, and it's not cheap anymore.

* There's no good way to forward SMTP headers when forwarding mail, or even to do anything with SMTP headers other than cut'n'paste them out of a properties box.

* Outlook doesn't support SPF, and only 2k7 supports DKIM with no plans to backport the functionality.

* Outlook lets a user set a blanket priority on outgoing messages; I can think of extremely few situations where this is useful functionality, but many where it is undesirable. As a result, priorities are almost useless in Outlook, in my experience, unless you're basing rules for specific senders who are known to use them properly.


That's a sucky email server (and client), and automatically putting meeting requests into my Schedule+ doesn't change that fact.

quote:

Edu(where I work) also has a tendency to not understand how in an organization outside edu, integrated authentication and the centralized management of a Microsoft shop is in fact a supremely valuable feature. I personally see it as one of the big blindspots of many *nix supporters...they can't seem to get it into their heads that no, in fact not every wants or even should be allowed to manage their own machines.


I've managed situations where users didn't run their own Unix/Linux workstations. When there was friction, it was sometimes because they wanted to be able to do certain things that were against site policy, but that didn't have anything to do with Unix. Well, except for the part where it seemed like they wanted to be able to run Windows games or something else they wouldn't admit. Nothing I've said implies users having to manage their own computing needs; in fact I'm the guy in threads who talks about X terms and thin client solutions having ridiculously low TCO but people don't seem interested even when thin client solutions would fit their needs perfectly. Same with Unix/Linux solutions.

It's funny that you mention centralized management and authentication, because that's historically a Unix strength (things are more complicated now). In the last few years you can get some expensive additional products just to properly install applications on a group of Windows clients and suddenly it's Windows that has strong central management capabilities? That's been trivial in typical Unix desktop environments since the 1980s.

It seems to me like you're approaching this problem thinking of all of Unix/Linux as a home user running Ubuntu. That's not any more representative of the IT environment than the home user running Vista Home Basic.
